name: TheAtlantic
text: The Islamic State turned Facebook into a global marketplace for looted artifacts. These vigilante archaeologists are trying to stop it, @Jenna_Scatena reports. https://t.co/3fWxHR0bi0

name: TheAtlantic
text: Books by Kiley Reid, Hilary Mantel, Margaret Atwood, and more Booker Prize nominees and winners in this week's #TheAtlanticBooksBriefing, by @latham_tori: https://t.co/Sp5NfsPlO9

name: TheAtlantic
text: "If campuses reopen to students but most faculty teach remotely, students and administrators who show up might see more clearly how staff are the connective tissue holding campuses together," writes @jselingo. https://t.co/lkpo3NT0QV

name: TheAtlantic
text: The South China Morning Post is arguably the world’s most important newspaper for what it tells us about media freedoms as China’s power grows. @TMcLaughlin3 looks inside a newsroom at the edge of autocracy: https://t.co/pRgBtqYgj1

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Archaeology operates within a contemporary setting and can contribute to conversations we are having today about how history is memorialized," @dmcarballo tells @DavidFrum: https://t.co/O9OwdtFrFV

name: TheAtlantic
text: "We cannot turn back the clock to a mythical 'Judeo-Christian America' in order to chart a new course for America’s moral imagination," @Jbloeffler writes: https://t.co/HzAxkyfafE

name: TheAtlantic
text: The former U.S. poet laureate Natasha Trethwey’s new memoir is awash in metaphor, its language a meditation on the role that poetry—and storytelling more broadly—can play in reconciling trauma, Hannah Giorgis writes. https://t.co/ukG90wltxT
